docs.snippet: During the past few months, two physicians at Massachusetts General Hospital who have been treating Leon Fleisher and Gary Graffman for their physical difficulties playing the piano, have been distributing questionnaires to other musicians about...
docs.lead_paragraph: During the past few months, two physicians at Massachusetts General Hospital who have been treating Leon Fleisher and Gary Graffman for their physical difficulties playing the piano, have been distributing questionnaires to other musicians about their pains and playing habits. The inquiry is expected to be part of a research project examining the disabilities of professional musicians. Questionnaires have been distributed to members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra; the doctors also plan to distribute the forms to students at the New England Conservatory, the Curtis Institute of Music and the Peabody Conservatory. The two physicians, Dr. Fred H. Hochberg, a neurologist, and Dr. Robert D. Leffert, an orthopedic surgeon, are part of a team of doctors treating medical problems of musicians at the hospital. About 250 patients have been seen since Gary Graffman went for treatment in 1980 after suffering from difficulties using his right hand. Mr. Graffman referred Mr. Fleisher to the doctors. Mr. Fleisher had to retire from his career as a pianist in the early 1960's because of debilitating cramps and tension in his right hand.

docs.snippet: Carlos Langoni, president of Brazil's central bank, said yesterday that Brazil would need more bank loans than the $4.4 billion already promised for this year, and that short-term financing needs for 1984 are now under discussion.   Mr. Langoni, who...
docs.lead_paragraph: Carlos Langoni, president of Brazil's central bank, said yesterday that Brazil would need more bank loans than the $4.4 billion already promised for this year, and that short-term financing needs for 1984 are now under discussion. Mr. Langoni, who met with Brazil's lenders in New York, did not say at a news conference after the meeting how much in new loans he would request. He said that the new credit was needed primarily because Brazil, despite an austerity program, has not been able to reduce public sector spending enough to raise the money that is needed for debt payment.

docs.snippet: The International Monetary Fund, which has approved a record amount of credit in the past year because of the foreign debt crisis, is now $2 billion short of the money it needs to finance its lending commitments, monetary officials said today.   The...
docs.lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund, which has approved a record amount of credit in the past year because of the foreign debt crisis, is now $2 billion short of the money it needs to finance its lending commitments, monetary officials said today. The $2 billion gap primarily grows out of the failure of Saudi Arabia to make a promised loan to the Fund that officials there had expected. The Saudis had given the Fund $8.5 billion in 1981 and 1982 and I.M.F. officials had been negotiating for an additional $4 billion to $5 billion, although the Saudis had never committed themselves to an amount.

headline.main: I.M.F. Short of Money For Loan Commitments

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: In fighting a libel suit, a news organization usually tries to prove that the offending article is true.  One opportunity to do that arises in pretrial depositions, when the defendants have a broad license to inquire into the plaintiff's activities,...
docs.lead_paragraph: In fighting a libel suit, a news organization usually tries to prove that the offending article is true. One opportunity to do that arises in pretrial depositions, when the defendants have a broad license to inquire into the plaintiff's activities, finances and personal life. Depositions are generally a matter of public record, meaning that the news organization can publish material from them and possibly embarrass the subject further. In several recent cases, the plaintiffs have countered that implicit threat, persuading judges to seal the records. Two such cases advanced in the courts recently, with differing results.

headline.main: SEALING OF PRETRIAL RECORD IS AT ISSUE IN 2 LIBEL CASES

docs.snippet: A popular Chilean folk singer was ostensibly singing a love ballad, but it was the forbidden political meaning and President Augusto Pinochet's Chile that excited the young people crammed into the smoky cafe.   ''Come and participate,'' the singer,...
docs.lead_paragraph: A popular Chilean folk singer was ostensibly singing a love ballad, but it was the forbidden political meaning and President Augusto Pinochet's Chile that excited the young people crammed into the smoky cafe. ''Come and participate,'' the singer, Payo Grondona, gently sang. ''Mobilize all your ardor without repression.'' As he began the next line, ''Tenderness united will never be conquered,'' the audience erupted into a roar accompanied by clapping. The line was a play on the Chilean protest call, ''A people united will never be conquered,'' and they sang it over and over. It was an example of the growing popularity of what is called ''canto nuevo,'' or ''new song,'' a music of protest and a search for roots that reflects a political reawakening among Chilean young people.

headline.main: MUSIC SPARKS POLITICAL PROTEST OF CHILE YOUTH

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a correspondent for The New York Times, lives in Rome.   One of the more unusual attractions of the Swiss canton of Valais is a 600-year-old organ, believed to be the oldest functioning organ in the world. It is housed in an...
docs.lead_paragraph: PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a correspondent for The New York Times, lives in Rome. One of the more unusual attractions of the Swiss canton of Valais is a 600-year-old organ, believed to be the oldest functioning organ in the world. It is housed in an 800-year-old fortress-church on a hill in Sion, the capital of the canton, and at 4 o'clock every Saturday afternoon from July 10 to Sept. 11 hymns, psalms and diverse sacred melodies by Orlando di Lasso, Tomas Luis de Victoria, Giovanni Gabrieli, Claudio Monteverdi, Dietrich Buxtehude, Giovanni Pergolesi and other pre-Baroque and Baroque composers will be performed there during the International Festival of Ancient Organ Music by organists from Uruguay, the Netherlands, East and West Germany and Switzerland. The organ, built in 1390 and most recently restored in 1954, is mounted on a wooden pulpit jutting out like a ship's bow from the rear wall of the Romanesque-Gothic church, once the Cathedral of Sion and one of Switzerland's most haunting edifices. Admission to the concerts is $2.50, students and children half price. A record of music that has been played on the historic instrument - representing composers ranging from Gabrieli to Haydn - is available for $12.50.

docs.snippet: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, 2 1/2 pounds over the light-heavyweight limit of 175 at the official weigh-in this morning, played the heavy in a figurative sense as well today. When he failed to attempt to lose the weight in the two hours allowed, his...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, 2 1/2 pounds over the light-heavyweight limit of 175 at the official weigh-in this morning, played the heavy in a figurative sense as well today. When he failed to attempt to lose the weight in the two hours allowed, his challenge of Michael Spinks for the title was first reduced to a 10-round nontitle event and then canceled by Spinks four hours before it was to be held. To cap the day, a skirmish involving two former world champions, a promoter and his father disrupted an evening news conference held to explain the cancellation. The L'Enfant Plaza Hotel, the fight headquarters where both contestants are staying, had local police officers guarding elevators in the lobby.

byline.original: By MICHAEL KATZ, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A human rights group said today that the military Government used cattle prods, rape and psychological torture to punish 30 students detained during the past month in a new crackdown on dissidents.
docs.lead_paragraph: A human rights group said today that the military Government used cattle prods, rape and psychological torture to punish 30 students detained during the past month in a new crackdown on dissidents.

headline.main: Rights Group Charges Uruguay With Torture

docs.snippet: Unseeded Diego Perez of Uruguay, scoring the greatest victory of his brief career, stunned top-seeded Guillermo Vilas, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, tonight in the United States Pro Tennis Championships.
docs.lead_paragraph: Unseeded Diego Perez of Uruguay, scoring the greatest victory of his brief career, stunned top-seeded Guillermo Vilas, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, tonight in the United States Pro Tennis Championships.

docs.snippet: Jose-Luis Clerc, who had been in a long slump, moved to the final of the $215,000 United States Pro tennis championship today with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Eliot Teltscher.   On Monday night the Argentine, the world's 10th-ranking player, will meet...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jose-Luis Clerc, who had been in a long slump, moved to the final of the $215,000 United States Pro tennis championship today with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Eliot Teltscher. On Monday night the Argentine, the world's 10th-ranking player, will meet 18-year-old Jimmy Arias, who stopped the streak of unseeded Diego Perez of Uruguay tonight, 6-2, 6-3. Clerc had not moved past the second round in 9 of his 10 previous tournaments. But he has been a different player here. One reason, he said, is that he quit experimenting with a new racquet and switched back to his original.

headline.main: Clerc, Out of Slump, In Final With Arias
